titleStmt.title: A message sent from the officers & souldiers in the Army, to the Kings Majesty in the Isle of Wyght, on Wednesday Novemb. 22. 1648. Communicating their last and finall resolutions, touching their disposall of his royal person. And their remonstrance and proposalls, for the executing of speedy justice, upon King, Lords, and Commons, who have acted contrary to the trust reposed in them by the people. With the charge of the Army thereupon, and their articles of high treason. By the appointment of his Excellency, the Lord Generall, and the generall Councell of Officers. Signed, John Rushworth Secr.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Army. Council.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 14 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A MESSAGE SENT FROM THE OFFICERS & SOULDIERS IN THE ARMY, TO THE Kings Maje≈øty in the I≈øle of Wyght, on Wedne≈øday Novemb. 22. 1648. Communicating their la≈øt and finall Re≈øolutions, touching their di≈øpo≈øall of his Royall Per≈øon. And their Remon≈øtrance and Propo≈øalls, for the executing of ≈øpeedy Ju≈øtice, upon King, Lords, and Commons, who have acted contrary to the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them by the People.
With the Charge of the Army thereupon, and their Articles of High Trea≈øon.
BY the appointment of his Excellency, the Lord Generall, and the generall Councell of Officers.
London, Printed for R. William≈øon, and are to be ≈øold in St. Dan≈øtons Church-yard, near Temple-Barre, 1648.

div.head: The Armies Me≈ø≈øage and Remon≈øtrance.
div.p: VVHereas we have endeavoured to Remon≈øtrate the danger and evill of the way you are in, and cleared the way unto what we have to propo≈øe, we ≈øhall with the ≈øame plainne≈ø≈øe and faithfulne≈ø≈øe, give you our apprehen≈øions of the remedies; for which purpo≈øe upon all the rea≈øons and con≈øiderations aforegoing, we proceed to offer, as followeth.

Fir≈øt, we conceive and hope, that from what hath before been ≈øaid, you may find abundant cau≈øe to forbear any further proceeding in this evill and mo≈øt dangerous Treaty, and to return to your former grounds in the Votes of Non-addre≈ø≈øes, and thereupon proceed to the ≈øetling and ≈øecuring of the Kingdom without and again≈øt the King, upon ≈øuch foundations as hereafter are tendred; but if notwith≈øtanding all the evills and dangers remon≈øtrated to lie even in the Treaty it ≈øelf, you will ye proceed in ≈øuch an evill way, we ≈øhall at lea≈øt de≈øire that you make ≈øure to avoid that main venome and mi≈øchief attending it. viz. The Kings re≈øtitution with impunity, &c. and that imperfect bargaining for partiall ju≈øtice again≈øt inferiour offenders; And for the avoidance of the≈øe, we propound.

1. That you would reject tho≈øe demands of the King, ≈øent to you on his and his Parties behalf, and (e≈øpecially in relation to that concerning his re≈øtitution or return to London with freedom, &c.) that it may be expre≈øly declared and provided by you, that, notwith≈øtanding any thing concluded, or to be concluded in this Treaty, the Per≈øon of the King may, and ≈øhall be proceeded again≈øt in a way of ju≈øtice, for the blood ≈øpilt, and the other evills
and mi≈øchiefs done by him, or by his Commi≈ø≈øion, Command or Procurement, and in order thereto ≈øhall be kept in ≈øafe cu≈øtody as formerly.

2. That for other Delinquents you would lay a ≈øide that particular bargaining Propo≈øition, which as we under≈øtand, the King hath refu≈øed in the termes you offered, and whereby all your ju≈øtice and mercy too would be rendred, to be dependant upon particular contract, with, and grant from the King; and not upon the judiciall power of the Kingdom in Parliament; We therefore de≈øire.

1. That that capitall and grand Authour of our troubles, the Per≈øon of the King, by who≈øe Commi≈ø≈øions, Commands, or procurement, and in who≈øe behalf, and for who≈øe intere≈øt only, (of will and power) all our Warres and troubles have been, (with all the mi≈øeries attending them,) may be ≈øpeedily brought to ju≈øtice, for the trea≈øon, blood and mi≈øchief, he is therein guilty of.

2. That a timely and peremptory day may be ≈øet for the Prince of Wales, and the Duke of York, to come in and render them≈øelves, by which time (if they do not) that then they may be immediatly declared incapable of any Government, or tru≈øt in this Kingdom, or the Dominions thereunto belonging, or of any kind of Right within the ≈øame, and thence to ≈øtand exiled for ever, as enemies and traytors, to dye without mercy, if ever after found and taken therein;) or if by the time limited, they or either of them do render them≈øelves, that then the Prince for his Capitall Delinquency (being in appearance next unto his Fathers,) may either be proceeded again≈øt in ju≈øtice, or remitted, according as upon his appearance he ≈øhall give ≈øatisfaction or not; concerning his being drawn into the rebellious engagements, he has appeared to head; and the Dake, as he ≈øhall give ≈øatisfaction, or not concerning his carriage in and ≈øince his going out of the Kingdom (being without leave) and in oppo≈øition or contempt of the Parliament and to the prejudice of the publike peace,) may accordingly be con≈øidered as to future tru≈øt, or not; But (however) that the E≈øtate and Revenue of the Crown may be ≈øeque≈øtred, and all the matter of co≈øtly pomp or ≈øtate ≈øu≈øpended for a good number of years, while the de≈øola ion and ≈øpoyles of the poor people made, by and in behalf
of that Family, and for that vain intere≈øt (the ≈øtate and greatne≈ø≈øe thereof) may be in good mea≈øure repaired, or recovered; And that the Revenue (≈øaving nece≈ø≈øary allowances for the Childrens maintenance, and to old Servants and creditors of the Crown, not Delinquents) and al≈øo the 100000 l. per annum, Voted to the Crown in Liew of the Court of Wards, may for tho≈øe years be di≈øpo≈øed towards publike charges, debts and dammages for the ea≈øing and le≈ø≈øoning of the peoples Contributions towards the ≈øame; ≈øo as the E≈øtates neither of the friends to publike intere≈øt, nor alone of the inferiour Enemies thereto, may bear wholly the burthen of that lo≈ø≈øe and charge, which by and for that Family, the Kingdom or the good people thereof have bin or (for future ≈øecurity) ≈øhall be put unto.

3. That for further ≈øatisfaction to publike ju≈øtice, Capitall puni≈øhment may be ≈øpeedily executed upon a competent number of his chief in≈øtruments al≈øo, both in the former and latter War, and (for that purpo≈øe) that ≈øome ≈øuch, of both ≈øorts, may be pitcht upon to be made examples of ju≈øtice in that kind, as are really in your hands or reach, ≈øo as their exception from pardon, may not be a mockery of Ju≈øtice in the face of God and men.

4. That the ≈øatisfaction of Arrears to the Souldiery. with other publike debts. and the competent reparation of publike Damages, (e≈øpecially and primarily of ≈øuch as voluntarily engaged for, and have con≈øtantly adhered to the common Cau≈øe, and ≈øuffered for the ≈øame) may be put into ≈øome orderly and equall, or proportionable way, &c.
Now (after publike ju≈øtice, had therewith the pre≈øent quieting of the Kingdom thus far provided for) we proceed in order, to the generall ≈øatisfaction, and ≈øetling of the Kingdom, as followeth.

1. That you would ≈øet ≈øome rea≈øonable and certain period to your own power, by which time that great and ≈øupream tru≈øt repo≈øed in you, ≈øhall be returned into the hands of the people, from, and for whom you received it; that ≈øo you may give them ≈øatisfaction and a≈ø≈øurance, that what you have contended for, again≈øt the King (for which they have been put to ≈øo much trouble, co≈øt, and lo≈ø≈øe of blood) hath been only for their Liberties and common Intere≈øt, and not for your own per≈øonall Intere≈øt, or power.

2. That (with a period to this Parliament, to be a≈ø≈øigned as ≈øhort as may be, with ≈øafety to the Kingdom, and publike intere≈øt thereof) there may be a ≈øound ≈øettlement of the peace, and future Government of the Kingdom, upon grounds of common Right, Freedom, and ≈øafety, to the effect here following.
1. That from the end of this, there may be a certain ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of future Parliaments (Annuall, or Bienniall) with ≈øecure provi≈øion.
1. For the certainty of their meeting, ≈øitting, and ending.
2. For the equall di≈øtribution of Elections thereunto, to render the Hou≈øe of Commons, as near as may be, an equall Repre≈øentative of the whole people electing.

3. For the certainty of the peoples meeting (according to ≈øuch Di≈øtributions) to elect, and for their full freedom in elections, provided, That none who have ingaged, or ≈øhall engage in War, again≈øt the right of Parliament, and intere≈øt of the Kingdom therein, or have adhered to the enemies thereof, may be capable of electing, or being elected (at lea≈øt during a competent number of years) nor any other, who ≈øhall oppo≈øe, or not joyn in agreement to this ≈øettlement.

4. For future clearing and a≈øcertaining the power of the ≈øaid Repre≈øentatives; in order to which, That it be declared, That as to the whole intere≈øt of the people of England) ≈øuch Repre≈øentatives have, and ≈øhall have the ≈øupream power and tru≈øt, as to the making of Lawes, Con≈øtitutions, and Offices, for the ordering, pre≈øervation, and Government of the whole; and as to the altering, and repealing, or aboli≈øhing of the ≈øame, the making of War, or peace; and as to the highe≈øt and finall Judgement, in all civill things, without further appeal to any created ≈øtanding power, and that all the people of this Nation, and all Officers of Ju≈øtice, and Mini≈øters of State (as ≈øuch) ≈øhall, in all ≈øuch things be accountable and ≈øubject thereunto, and bound and concluded thereby, provided, That,

1. They may not cen≈øure, or que≈øtion any man after the end of this Parliament, for any thing ≈øaid or done in reference to the late Wars, or publique differences, ≈øaving in execution of ≈øuch determinations of this Parliament, as ≈øhall be left in force at the
ending thereof in relation to ≈øuch as have ≈øerved the King again≈øt the Parliament.

2. They may not render up, or give, or take away any the foundations of common Right, Liberty or Safety contained in this ≈øettlement and agreement. But that the power of the≈øe two things (la≈øt mentioned) ≈øhall be alwayes under≈øtood to be re≈øerved from, and not entru≈øted to the ≈øaid Repre≈øentatives.

5. For liberty of entring de≈ø≈øents in the ≈øaid Repre≈øentatives. That, in ca≈øe of corruption, or abu≈øe in the≈øe matters of highe≈øt tru≈øt, the People may be in capacity to know who are free therof, and who guilty, to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ only they may avoid the futher tru≈øting of ≈øuch, but without further penalty to any for their free judgments there.

2. That no King be hereafter admitted, but upon the election of, and as upon tru≈øt from the People, by ≈øuch their Repre≈øentatives, nor without fir≈øt di≈øclaming and di≈øavowing all pretence to a negative voyce, again≈øt the determinations of the ≈øaid Repre≈øentatives, or Commons in Parliament; and that to be done in ≈øome certain form, more clear then heretofore in the Coronation Oath.

The≈øe matters of generall ≈øettlement (viz. That concerning a period to this Parliament, and the other particulars thence following heitherto) we propound, to be declared and provided by this Parl. or by the authority of the Commons therein, and to be further e≈øtabli≈øhed by a generall Contract, or Agreement of the people, with their ≈øub≈øcriptions thereunto, and that (withall) it may be provided, That none may be capable of any benefit by the Agreement, who ≈øhall not con≈øent and ≈øub≈øcribe thereunto; nor any King to be admitted to the Crown, or other per≈øon to any Office, or place of publike tru≈øt, without expre≈ø≈øe accord, and ≈øub≈øcription to the ≈øame.

We have thus plainly, and faithfully propounded our apprehen≈øions, how the evill and danger of the pre≈øent Treaty may in good mea≈øure be avoyded, and our further conceptions of a way, wherein, hopefully through the ble≈ø≈øing of God (if mo≈øt men be not given up, ≈øome to unju≈øt domination, or particular Intere≈øt, the re≈øt to ≈øervitude) the Kingdom may be quieted, future di≈øturbances prevented, the common Rights and Liberties provided for,
and the Peace and Government of the Kingdome ≈øetled, to a ju≈øt publick Intere≈øt; and this wee have ≈øet forth in ≈øuch hands and particulars, which (if you'l but ≈øet a≈øide, for the time, le≈ø≈øe importaint matters) may mo≈øt of them be brought to effect, and the re≈øt a≈ø≈øured, and put into a good way of effect, within a few Moneths, ≈øo as you might then ea≈øe the Kingdome from the burthen of the greate≈øt part of that force, which otherwi≈øe (in ca≈øe of Accommodation with the King) you will be nece≈ø≈øitated, for a much longer time (probable for many yeares) to keep on, upon the publick charge, unle≈ø≈øe, upon the Accommodation you would give up all to the Kings power again, a ‚Ä¢ d expo≈øe tho≈øe that have engaged again≈øt him, as ≈øacrifices to his and the Cavaliers Reveng: And (for our parts) let but that way of ju≈øtice be effectually pro≈øecuted and the ≈øettlement of publick Intere≈øt (upon which foundations as are afore propounded) be a≈ø≈øured to us and the Kingdome, and put into a cour≈øe of effect (and we ≈øhall not only imbrace with chearfullne≈ø≈øe, but ≈øhall with eagern ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe de≈øire di≈øcharge from our pre≈øent ≈øervice, and ≈øhall be mo≈øt ready to disband all, or part, as ≈øhall be though ≈øit, the Arrears of the ≈øouldiers being ≈øatisfied.

THere is a generall Report, that the Army is ingaged to expedite a Me≈ø≈øage to his Me≈ø≈øage, to adverti≈øe him of their proceedings, and Overtures, for the executing of Ju≈øtice, and bring of all Delinquents to a ≈øpeedy Tryall; to the end, that the enemies of peace, may be all remanded in, and the differences of this ≈øangui≈øhing Kingdom ≈øpeedily united and compo≈øed.
